title-group.article-title: The Influence of Process Drama on Elementary Students’ Written Language

author-notes.corresp: Alida Anderson, American University, School of Education, Teaching, and Health, 4400 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20016, USA Email: aanderso@american.edu

abstract.p: This article describes the influence of process drama on fourth grade students’ written language productivity and specificity. Participants included 16 students with learning and/or behavioral challenges at an urban public charter school. The influence of process drama on students’ written language was compared across contextualized and decontextualized activities to identify associations between activities and language outcomes. Significant increases in students’ written language productivity and specificity were observed in contextualized dramatic arts activities, as compared to decontextualized language arts activities. Implications and directions for future research in arts integration within content area instruction for students in inclusive settings are discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This study contributes to the development of a literacy approach for students with language-based learning disabilities (LD) and developmental disabilities (DD), as well as those with literacy failure due to limited economic resources or socioeconomic status (SES) and emotional-behavioral disabilities (EBD) in an inclusive urban classroom setting. An unquestionable hallmark of recent educational initiatives is the concern for literacy achievement in students identified as “at-risk” (Novosel, Deshler, Pollitt, Mark, & Mitchell, 2011) for school failure due to a variety of learning challenges (Williams, Ari, & Dortch, 2011). One avenue for informing literacy initiatives in these populations involves the development of an instructional practice aimed at increasing students’ linguistic productivity and specificity through literate language feature (LLF) use.

Students who struggle in their use of precise and specific language (i.e., literate language) in academic contexts are among those at-risk for school failure (Scott, 2004; Ukrainetz, 2001; Wallach, Chariton, & Christie, 2009; Westby, 2006). In contrast, students who use literate language are characterized as those who “talk like books” and are reported to perform better on academic tasks than students who do not (Wallach & Butler, 1994; Westby & Torres-Velasquez, 2000). However, studies examining the development of students’ language specificity and productivity in inclusive classrooms are few, and have not been conducted with diverse populations of students at-risk for literacy failure (see Ukrainetz, 2006 for a discussion). The current study examines the influence of process drama as a contextualized language activity on literacy outcomes (i.e., written productivity and specificity) in a classroom of fourth grade students at an urban charter school.

This line of inquiry is relevant to current education policy, research, and practice. At present, there is an emphasis on arts-based learning as a way to reach and teach all children (U.S. Department of Education, 2010), and drama-based interventions are being adopted by education practitioners in an effort to improve students’ literacy outcomes (Hoyt, 1992; Rose, Parks, Androes, & McMahon, 2010). However, to date, the relation between drama-based intervention and language-learning outcomes is underspecified (Podlozny, 2000). The current study contributes to the literature by framing drama-based intervention as a contextualized language environment, allowing for a greater specification of the relation between drama and literacy outcomes.

sec.title: Conceptual Framework
sec.p: Literature related to development of linguistic specificity and productivity, contextualized–decontextualized language, and drama in education frames the current study. Cognitive and social learning theories explain children’s language development in terms of linguistic specificity and productivity. As children engage in symbolic representation, assimilation and accommodation (Piaget, 1926, 1963), and social interaction (Vygotsky, 1978), they use increasingly complex and specific language features such as adverbs, conjunctions (causal, temporal, and sequential), noun phrases, and mental/linguistic verbs (Anderson, 2011; Curenton & Justice, 2004; Paul, 2002; Pellegrini, 1985). Social interaction theory has been used to interpret children’s increased understanding and use of specific language features such as noun phrases, conjunctive clauses, adverbs, and mental and linguistic verbs in dramatic-symbolic play contexts with peers (Kempe, 2003; Pellegrini, 1985; Peter, 2003).

Oral and written language mutually influence students’ development of linguistic specificity and productivity, since the structure and function of the language features is shared in expressing relationships among ideas (e.g., coordinating and subordinating conjunctions), open class-content words, noun phrases with attributive adjectives, relative clauses, and prepositional phrases (i.e., LLFs; Paul, 2002). Thus, students with problems in linguistic specificity in oral language evident first in early childhood, also have difficulties with LLF use in oral and written language (Scott, 2004). In particular, students with language-based exceptionalities (e.g., LD, DD) have documented struggles with linguistic specificity and productivity stemming from early deficits in semantic diversity and syntactic knowledge (Scott, 1994, 1995). Likewise, students from low SES backgrounds enter school with less semantic diversity and syntactic knowledge than their age-matched peers from middle-to-high SES backgrounds (Hart & Risley, 1995). Similarly, students with EBD struggle with linguistic productivity and specificity in academic settings due to emotional and/or behavioral issues affecting motivation and engagement (Brown, 2007; Foley, 2001; Nelson, Benner, Neill, & Stage, 2006).

sec.title: Contextualized–Decontextualized Language Use
sec.p: A number of language researchers distinguish between two types of language use: contextualized and decontextualized (see Figure 1; Paul, 2002; Scott, 1994).

caption.p: Differences Between Contextualized and Decontextualized Language

sec.p: Contextualized language is related to “everyday” language activities like face-to-face conversations, in which shared knowledge and vocabulary, gestures, interactive negation of meaning, and listener feedback facilitate the apprehension of meaning (Snow, 1991b). Contextualized language is associated with oral language, simple syntax, and repetition of high frequency vocabulary. As well, contextualized language often refers to the here-and-now, referencing of objects, people, and actions in the immediate environment (Westby, 1994).

In contrast, decontextualized language is associated with classroom language tasks, particularly reading and writing text, in which the speaker is removed from the context. Thus, decontextualized language is “comprehensible to an unknown audience without support from others” (Westby, 1994, p. 56). Thus, decontextualized language tasks such as text reading are grounded in time and space, do not assume shared knowledge and vocabulary, and are often linguistically complex (De Temple, Wu, & Snow, 2009).

Notably, both contextualized and decontextualized languages involve LLF use. Children are exposed to LLFs in events such as story sharing and symbolic play contexts with increasing shift to less familiar contexts such as school-based tasks (Pellegrini & Galda, 1998). Thus, children’s language production in literacy contexts such as storybook sharing and narration is typically characterized as their first experience with explicit (Snow, 1991b) and decontextualized (Snow, 1991a) language. Literacy researchers identify LLF use as the bridge between oral and written discourse, since LLF use develops across contextualized, oral language activities such as conversations, and also is required in decontextualized, written language activities (Dickinson & McCabe, 1991; Kavanaugh, 1991; Paul, 2002).

The contextualized–decontextualized language continuum has been used to explain children’s attainment of school-based literacy skills, particularly in relation to LLF use. For instance, Westby (1994), in her work with school age populations, used this continuum to describe students’ attainment of school-based literacy skills across a variety of academic contexts (e.g., language arts, science, and mathematics). She found increased LLF use to differentiate high-performing from low-performing students (also see Pellegrini & Galda, 1998, pp. 120-155 for a review). Wallach and Butler (1994) also indicated associations between elementary age students’ academic performance and linguistic specificity, in that students who effectively used LLFs early on in their academic careers were more likely to meet teachers’ expectations and to be rewarded, encouraged, and motivated in school than students who did not.

The contextualized–decontextualized continuum has also been used to characterize development of specific language registers in African American English, in which children use language features such as noun phrases, conjunctions, and adverbs (i.e., LLFs) in less familiar or unknown contexts (i.e., school), as compared to familiar (i.e., home) (Charity, Scarborough, & Griffin, 2004; Curenton & Justice, 2004; Heath, 1983). In this application, researchers have described how children transition from familiar or contextualized oral language communication of events, to unfamiliar or decontextualized forms of classroom-based oral and written discourse.

Only a few studies, however, have investigated the influence of context on written language (Craig, 2006; Jones & Pellegrini, 1996). Jones and Pellegrini (1996) found that contextualized writing, as defined by interaction between first grade students and their friends as well as their teachers, had a facilitating effect on the quality of students’ written narratives, in comparison to solitary writing activities. Craig (2006) also examined the effect of a contextualized interactive approach on kindergarten age children’s early literacy skills. Features of this contextualized instruction included teachers’ use of supportive, interactive discourse to mediate children’s participation and maximize children’s involvement (Mariage, 2001; Pinnell & McCarrier, 1994). Children participating in contextualized activities made greater gains in word reading and comprehension achievement than children participating in solitary reading activities. Ukrainetz et al. (2005) found that an interactive oral narrative storytelling activity using picture sequences influenced early elementary age students’ academic (i.e., decontextualized language such as LLFs) and artistic (e.g., quality of ideas, content, interest, individuality, and engagement) oral expression.

sec.title: Contextualized–decontextualized language use in students with exceptionalities
sec.p: Students with language-based LD have been reported to use fewer LLFs across contextualized and decontextualized activities, particularly in oral narrative storytelling, despite similar exposure (Gillam & Johnston, 1992; Kaderavek & Sulzby, 2000; Ukrainetz & Gillam, 2009). However, only a few studies have compared children with and without language-based exceptionalities across contextualized and decontextualized activities (Anderson, 2011; McKeough, 1984; Ukrainetz & Gillam, 2009). McKeough (1984) showed a strong relationship between LLF use and dramatic play in oral narrative retellings of 8-to-12-year-old students with and without LD. Ukrainetz and Gillam (2009) found both elementary age children with and without LD to show increased oral language productivity and specificity using contextualized support (pictures and interactive practice) in narrative storytelling. More recently, Anderson (2011) found that preschool age children with and without language impairment had significantly greater linguistic specificity and productivity (as measured through LLF use) in contextualized play, as compared to storybook reading, children’s presumed earliest decontextualized language experience (Snow, 1991b).

sec.title: Dramatic Arts in Education
sec.p: Dramatic arts integration is generally defined as the linking of drama with a content area for the purposes of reaching a deeper level of engagement, learning, and reflection than would be possible without inclusion of the art form. In a drama-integrated classroom, students are working “with” and “through” drama to reach academic, social, and personal goals (Cornett, 2007, p. 13). Throughout parts of the world such as Canada, England, Ireland, Turkey, and Australia, drama in education has been recognized as a dynamic methodology for teaching (Okvuran, 2010). Dramatic arts integration is most commonly identified as a process-oriented approach, which activates “learners’ imaginations by using dramatic structures associated with a larger theatrical field to explore content area curriculum, texts, relationships readers have with texts, issues connected to texts, and other aspects of literacy learning in diverse educational settings” (Schneider, Crumpler, & Rogers, 2006, p. XIV).

Generally, practitioners who implement dramatic arts integration support students in committing to a fictional world in which they identify with and assume multiple roles. In this context, students operate in two frames: the “meaning frame,” where understanding is shaped and manifested, and the “expressive frame,” where understanding is communicated (Morgan & Saxton, 1989, p. 21). Teachers facilitate learning experiences using structures within the dramatic context; teachers also may position themselves within the dramatic context as a character (Baldwin, 2008, p. 23). The organization of dramatic structures to support student learning is generally known as process drama (Cornett, 2007).

Dramatic arts approaches have been reported to influence students’ learning in a variety of content areas such as mathematics (see Sengün & Iskenderogulu, 2010, for a review), science (Kamen, 1992; Kase-Polisini, & Spector, 1992) and vocabulary (Demircioglu, 2010). Research on the integration of drama and literacy activities has focused on the idea that the arts influence academic and social/emotional outcomes, leading to students’ improved reading proficiency and academic self-concept in comparison to uninvolved students (Catterall, Chapleau, & Iwanaga, 1999; Eisner, 1998). In addition, the relationship between dramatic arts activities and student achievement has been shown to be powerful for students from diverse socioeconomic, linguistic, and cultural backgrounds (Ingram & Seashore, 2003; Kempe, 2003). In particular, researchers have reported reliable causal relationships between elementary and secondary students’ increased verbal skills and participation in dramatic arts activities (Hetland & Winner, 2000; Podlozny, 2000). Kempe (2003) explained the contribution of dramatic arts to language learning as increasing students’ social capital through their identification, analysis, and use of aural, visual and verbal grammar of spoken English to understand and express discourse appropriate for a range of situations.

sec.title: Dramatic arts integration and students with exceptionalities
sec.p: Research on the relationship between dramatic arts activities and literacy skills for students with exceptionalities (LD, EBD, and DD) has identified positive influences on reading comprehension, oral, and written language production (Mason & Steedly, 2006). A similar result of drama integration was reported from gains made by elementary age students with LD participating in a creative drama program, which led to their increased social and oral expressive language skills (de la Cruz, 1995). The impact of integrated arts activities on students’ social, cognitive, and language skills has also been documented from teachers’ and parents’ evaluations (Mason, Steedly, & Thormann, 2005).

The social validity of dramatic arts-based approaches has been established in some studies. Students with primary difficulties in social and language skills (those identified with autism spectrum disorder, ASD) made robust gains in their social communication understanding and concept development (Peter, 2003; Schieman & Nichols, 2010). Peter’s (2003) dramatic play-based intervention for elementary age students with ASD supported their development of symbolic representations, social interactions, and emotional responses with peers. These findings indicated that the contextualized learning environment of dramatic play influenced students’ language, social, and emotional skills.

sec.title: Rationale
sec.p: There is promising research to indicate that dramatic arts activities enhance verbal learning and academic engagement for involved students (Deasy, 2002; Podlozny, 2000), including evidence that the use of dramatic arts within academic settings potentially mediates linguistic specificity in students’ written language (Wagner, 1998). However, to date, there have been insufficient explanations of how and why arts activities, including drama-based interventions, are related to academic outcomes (Winner & Cooper, 2000). The current study provides one potential explanation for the relation between dramatic arts and linguistic productivity and specificity in written language; namely by framing process drama as a case of contextualized language learning, and assessing linguistic productivity and specificity through LLF use. It is expected that process drama activities will operate as a facilitating mechanism of linguistic specificity and productivity for students who struggle with decontextualized language use, since the dramatic context supports them to understand and use specific and precise discourse across both oral and written activities.

Evidence to support this expectation includes Pellegrini’s (1985) assessment of linguistic specificity and productivity in preschoolers’ oral discourse, in which he reported highest correlations between contextualized dramatic play and LLF use over constructive and solitary play. Children’s increased LLF use in dramatic-play was interpreted as evidence of their mental representation of events and objects. As children acquired and integrated information to form increasingly sophisticated mental representations, they relied on increasingly specific and complex language features (i.e., LLFs) to express their ideas.

Other researchers have found children to use more LLFs in ideational, symbolic play, as compared to constructive or solitary object play (Culatta, 1994; Pellegrini, Galda, Bartini, & Charak, 1998). Van Oers (1998) suggested that children’s LLF use was linked to their development of meaningful abstract thinking or the ability to recontextualize previously experienced events, since they described temporal and sequential information through specific features such as conjunctive phrases. As well, children have been shown to understand and use specific features such as noun phrases, conjunctive clauses, adverbs, and mental/linguistic verbs most reliably in dramatic-play contexts with peers (Pellegrini, 1985; Peter, 2003). Thus, the context of dramatic-play has been linked to children’s linguistic specificity since it supports their symbolic interactions and is linked to concrete objects in the environment, as well as to more abstract and socially mediated symbols (Kempe, 2003).

The contextualized–decontextualized continuum of language use offers another possible explanation of “how” dramatic arts activities facilitate linguistic productivity and specificity across oral and written language use. Linguistic specificity and productivity develops through “facilitating mechanisms” of interaction (Luciarello & Nelson, 1987) and setting (Dickinson & McCabe, 1991, 2001; Snow, 1991a, 1991b; Wells, 1985), both of which are critical aspects of dramatic arts integration.

While these studies have examined the relation between dramatic play and LLF use in early childhood and elementary age children, they have focused on oral, rather than written language, and have not explicitly framed dramatic arts integration as a contextualized language environment. The current study extends this line of inquiry by explicating this relation. The study poses two guiding research questions to examine the influence of process drama on students’ written language:

list-item.p: What is the influence of process drama on students’ written language productivity?
What is the influence of process drama on students’ written language specificity?

sec.title: Method
sec.p: The next section provides information on the participating students and teachers and the school setting. This information is followed by a description of the intervention, data collection, and analysis procedures of the study.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: In the present study, 16 fourth grade students (12 male, 4 female) participated in drama and language arts activities as part of their academic school day. All of the students had scored significantly below grade level (more than 2 years) on standardized reading and/or writing measures (Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skills (DIBELS), Good & Kaminski, 2002). The majority (approximately 80%) of the classroom population was eligible for special education services based on diagnoses of LD, DD, and EBD.

The classroom teacher played an active role in the project as a participant-observer and as a drama character in-role. This teacher had a master’s degree in special education and 15 years of experience as a special education classroom teacher. At the time of the study, the teacher was enrolled in his 6 month of a year-long professional development program to integrate arts-based activities within content area instruction. The researcher and graduate assistants volunteered their time at the school to support the implementation of the arts-integration program through coaching activities. One graduate student trained in discourse analysis assisted with transcription and coding of students’ written language samples.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: The study took place in an urban charter school whose mission was to integrate the arts within classroom content area instruction across kindergarten through eighth grade. The school used an inclusive classroom model to serve a diverse array of students with and without disabilities. Sixty percent of the students attending the charter school had identified disabilities (e.g., DD, EBD, LD, and physical/motor disabilities). Across kindergarten through eighth grade, the majority of students without disabilities (approximately 40% of the school population) functioned at least 2 years below grade level in reading and written language skills. Each classroom had between 12 and 16 students and a master’s level certified special educator as well as a general education teacher. Over 95% of the school’s student population qualified for free and reduced lunch on the basis of their family’s economic status.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: The process drama intervention occurred over an 8-week period in hour-long sessions averaging twice weekly. Initial activities began with students during their third month of the school year and concluded at the end of the 6 month. The initial 2 weeks of the intervention included decontextualized written language activities. These activities served as students’ introduction to the research team, activities and procedures. During this 2-week baseline period, students participated in an orientation to the dramatic arts medium.

The next 4 weeks involved students’ selection of, and acting in drama roles with the research team and classroom teacher in the fictional world created by a contemporary adaptation of Little Red Riding Hood. During this time, students participated in dramatic events with the researchers and completed contextualized written language tasks. For example, students were grouped for activities involving observation, interpretation, and discussion of the story events and character motives. Students participated in tableaux activities in which they illustrated ideas or concepts using nonverbal gesture and body positions. Assuming the role of protagonist, students completed independent in-role writing activities. The final 2 weeks involved decontextualized data collection through follow-up writing prompts.

sec.title: Dependent variables
sec.p: Students’ written language productivity was measured through the number of total words (NTW), number of different words (NDW) and number of utterances (UTT) they used in each of the written language samples collected over the course of the intervention period. These productivity measures have been shown to accurately and reliably assess students’ written language production in both contextualized as well as decontextualized activities (e.g., Greenhalgh & Strong, 2001). Students’ written language specificity was measured through semantic diversity and expressed as the proportion of NDW/NTW. In addition to this semantic diversity measure, students’ use of LLFs was assessed, since LLF use has been shown to enable speakers to be specific and precise in both contextualized and decontextualized oral and written communication (Anderson, 2011; Curenton & Justice, 2004; Greenhalgh & Strong, 2001; Jones, 2003; Ukrainetz, 1998). Literate language features included simple elaborated noun phrases (SENP; e.g., a dog, the girl), complex elaborated noun phrases (CENP; e.g., the red apple, our little dog), adverbs (ADV), conjunctions (CONJ), and mental and linguistic verbs (MLV; e.g., talk, think, feel). Number and frequency of LLFs, calculated as a proportion of students’ NTW, were used to describe changes in linguistic specificity of written discourse across activities.

sec.title: Independent variable
sec.p: Students participated in written language sampling activities individually with the research team at three points in the project: (a) genre writing before the intervention period (WL1); (b) decontextualized genre writing at the end of the intervention period (WL2); and (c) contextualized in-role writing during the intervention period (WL3).

sec.title: Fidelity measures
sec.p: Macro-level qualitative analysis of students’ written discourse was conducted to obtain information about their attitudes towards literacy learning activities as well as their topic focus and maintenance during written language activities. Preliminary data collection during the pre-intervention interviews indicated students had a limited understanding of the activities and skills comprising language arts as an instructional area. Students reported a range of ideas from science- to history-focused. Only one of the 16 students responded to the question of what is your favorite language arts activity with a statement that reflected his accurate understanding of language arts. Most students reported consistently high attitudes towards literacy activities (listening, reading, speaking, and writing); however, their self-reported, high literacy ratings contradicted their interview responses to probes such as, what do you like the most/least about language arts. In response to these probes, students stated that they did not like activities involving writing, reading, or speaking; and, in particular, that writing made their “hand hurt”.

Due to the inconsistency of baseline attitudinal data and students’ limited knowledge base and awareness of language arts components, we included an instructional focus within the process drama activities as an orientation to language arts and process drama. The intensity of the eight-session intervention period with the fourth grade class focused solely on the relationship between students’ contextualized process drama experience and its impact on decontextualized written language use.

In the current study, methods of inquiry included quantitative and qualitative analysis of students’ language samples across baseline, intervention and follow-up periods. Micro analysis of students’ written language was conducted via coding for productivity and specificity of language use. Two graduate students trained in language analysis discourse methods participated with the researcher in coding of students’ writing samples. In order to ensure fidelity, inter-rater agreement reached 95% accuracy level between coders, with disagreements resolved via conference.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Paired sample t tests were used to compare differences among variables of interest across written language contexts for the group of students. Data cleaning measures were taken to remove outliers and to check normality assumptions of the sample (Duncan, 1975).

sec.title: Written Language Productivity
sec.p: Table 1 shows means, standard deviations, and significance levels for students’ written language productivity across baseline decontextualized written language (WL1), follow-up decontextualized written language (WL2), and contextualized written language (WL3) activities.

caption.p: Means (and Standard Deviations) of Written Language Productivity Measures for Students (n = 16)

fn.p: Note: NTW = number of total words; NDW = number of different words; UTT = number of utterances.

sec.p: In the decontextualized written language activities, students were asked to write about a character and setting from their language arts assignment. In the contextualized writing activity, students were asked to select a setting and character from their language arts-drama integrated assignment and write from the character’s perspective (e.g., in-role). This activity was considered contextualized since students’ writing occurred in the context of the drama activity.

The dependent variable measures of written language productivity were NTW, NDW, and UTT used in each writing sample. Paired independent sample t tests revealed significant increases in students’ decontextualized written productivity as measured by differences in their production of NTW (p = .04), NDW (p = .03), and UTT (p = .00) from baseline to follow-up writing. The most significant increases in students’ written productivity were observed between decontextualized genre writing (WL2) and contextualized in-role writing (WL3). Data show students produced significantly more NTW and NDW in contextualized in-role (WL3) than in decontextualized (WL2) writing (ps = .01 and .00, respectively). Students’ most significant increases in written language productivity occurred between decontextualized baseline (WL1) and follow-up (WL2) writing in UTT (p = .00). As expected, students also showed increased UTT production between decontextualized (WL2) and contextualized in-role (WL3) writing (p = .03). No comparison was made between decontextualized baseline genre (WL1) and contextualized in-role writing (WL3) since students’ WL1 baseline was likely to be impacted by the external validity factor of familiarity with the researchers and procedures of the task.

sec.title: Written Language Specificity
sec.p: Table 2 shows means, standard deviations, and significance levels for written language specificity across the baseline decontextualized written language (WL1), follow-up decontextualized written language (WL2), and contextualized in-role written language (WL3) activities. Dependent measures of written language specificity included semantic diversity (NDW/NTW), frequency of LLF use (LLF/NTW), total number of LLFs, number of simple elaborated noun phrases (SENP), number of complex elaborated noun phrases (CENP), number of adverbs (ADV), number of conjunctions (CONJ), and number of mental/linguistic verbs (MLV). Similar to written language productivity, students showed significant differences between decontextualized writing and contextualized in-role writing in their increased use of LLF (p = .05), CENP (p = .05), CONJ (p = .04) and MLV (p = .05) in contextualized writing samples.

caption.p: Means (and Standard Deviations) of Written Language Specificity Measures for Students (n = 16)

fn.p: Note: Semantic Diversity = NDW/NTW; LLF Frequency = Number of literate language features (LLF)/NTW; LLF = Total number of LLF; SENP = Simple elaborated noun phrases; CENP = Complex elaborated noun phrases; ADV = Adverbs; CONJ = Conjunctions; MLV = Mental/linguistic verbs.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This section summarizes the influences of the dramatic arts intervention on students’ written language. Implications for practice and future research are discussed, as well as conclusions.

sec.title: Influences on Written Language
sec.p: The dramatic arts intervention was positively associated with gains in students’ decontextualized and contextualized written language, both in terms of productivity and specificity. Significant differences in students’ contextualized and decontextualized written language indicated that the contextualized in-role writing experience had a mediating effect on students’ written linguistic specificity as it did for their productivity. Students produced twice as many LLFs in contextualized as compared to decontextualized written language activities. There were significant increases in students’ use of CENPs in their detailed descriptions and elaborations. Students used significantly more CONJs to convey temporal, causal, and sequential ideas in contextualized written language. Also, students used significantly more MLVs to communicate feelings, moods, and expressions in contextualized written language activities as compared with decontextualized written language activities.

The relation between the drama intervention and students’ written language can be explained by students’ contextualized in-role writing, in that the drama context provided scaffolding for students to mentally represent concepts and ideas, and then to use oral and written language in the service of expression (see Durham, 2010). In other words, since the students were situated within the text (drama), their writing in-role was contextualized and was likely to reflect increased specificity and productivity “as it rose naturally in response to the situations encountered” (Cremin, Goouch, Blakemore, Goff, & Macdonald, 2006, p. 276).

One of the most interesting aspects of the dramatic arts intervention was in the apparent transfer from students’ gains in contextualized writing to decontextualized genre writing. Arguably, this increase in students’ decontextualized written language productivity resulted from their exposure, experience, and success with contextualized in-role writing. In other words, the observed gains in decontextualized written language productivity were likely influenced by students’ direct experience with the learning context as well as their emotional engagement with the subject matter, supporting social-interactionist framework (Ukrainetz, 2006). Anecdotally, teachers shared that students who received individualized occupational therapy service for written language, and who had been previously classified as “non-writers,” were attempting to write independently during their therapy sessions in the period following the drama intervention. While this finding was not systematically examined in the present study, teachers’ spontaneous reports do offer an interesting extension of the reported findings.

This evidence is encouraging, and indicates that with more time and experience in using linguistically specific discourse in contextualized activities, students could demonstrate more substantial increases to their decontextualized written language productivity and specificity. It is likely that some students would continue to need concrete and representational aspects of the context to produce linguistically specific discourse. This interpretation is consistent with findings on the ways in which students with language-based learning challenges benefit from concrete and/or representational forms to support concept development and expression of ideas (Anderson, 2011; Durham, 2010; Ukrainetz, 1998, 2001).

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: The findings of this study have important implications for the development of interventions to support students’ literacy skill acquisition through meaningful and authentic experiences that foster practice and capacity building in decontextualized language use through contextualized language activities. Other researchers contend that students’ engagement enables them to create, express, and extend their ideas through a meaningful context that empowers them “to make connections between the thinking involved in different parts of the drama with their thinking in real life contexts” (McGuiness, 1999, p. 55). The current study provides empirical support for this contention.

As well, the information about the use of dramatic arts activities and students’ written language outcomes has implications for practitioners and caregivers working with students with diverse literacy learning needs, as it may challenge conventional learning expectations held for them (Flowers & Flowers, 2008; Shepherd, 2011). These results demonstrate the ways in which context supports students’ increasing exposure to, and success with literacy learning.

This work also implies a shift in the way that teachers position themselves in the classroom (e.g., Ye, Varelas, & Guajardo, 2011). Conventional approaches to remediation and literacy instruction tend to focus exclusively on teacher-directed examinations of text (i.e., decontextualized). Dramatic arts integration provides an alternative context in which students and teachers coexist and engage in activities that “support and give opportunities for inference and the understanding of subtext and the meaning and emotions lying behind spoken and written words” (Baldwin, 2008, p. 52).

A final implication of this work is the effectiveness of shifting the focus of student experience from that of passive observer to active explorer of the meaning of text by actualizing it or performing its meaning (Iser, 1989; Schneider et al., 2006). Furthermore, the fictional environment of process drama encouraged individual students to take risks and develop ideas rather than to simply receive information (Wagner, 1998, p. 10).

sec.title: Future Research
sec.p: One of the untapped areas of this study is the relationship between students’ participation in the dramatic arts activities and their engagement with literacy learning. Anecdotal evidence from the classroom’s special educator, occupational therapist, and speech therapist indicated that the majority of the students showed increased willingness to participate in and positive attitudes towards written language activities. This is a clear area for future research to address insofar as student engagement and motivation played a key role in written language production over the course of the intervention period.

Additional research in this area could aim to involve teachers in generating performance-based rubrics (see Mason & Steedly, 2006) to assess students’ language, social, and arts skills in dramatic activities, which could then be triangulated with students’ written language data. Another direction for research could include behavioral observations and parent/caregiver evaluations of students’ literacy learning before, during, and after dramatic arts integrated activities. Informal analysis of practitioner data revealed that students made significant gains in their engagement, motivation, and willingness to participate in both contextualized and decontextualized written language activities. The relationship between student engagement and learning through the arts has been demonstrated in arts integrated settings with students having LD (e.g., Durham, 2010), and clearly fits within the social-interactionist framework used in contextualized language intervention (see Ukrainetz, 2006 for a review).

Further research regarding the influence of dramatic arts integration on literacy learning could focus on the social and emotional transfer of ideas and thoughts. For instance, most art forms merge the emotion of one’s inner world with the representational systems of external environment, or outer world (Kempe, 2003). Therefore, a learning context comprising inner emotions and outer world conventions may foster students’ increased command and voice in written language, as evident in students’ increased use of LLFs such as mental, linguistic, and descriptive language.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study extends previous research by incorporating analysis of elementary age students’ expressive written language across contextualized and decontextualized activities to identify associations between skills and context of use. The evidence generated by this study supports process drama as a contextualized literacy activity to address linguistic specificity, motivation, and engagement among students with diverse learning needs.

ack.p: Appreciation is extended to the teachers, students and administrators at the charter school in which the intervention project occurred. Special thanks extended to Linda Krakaur for leadership of the drama intervention activities. Appreciation is extended to Patrick Shaw for his classroom collaboration, and to Sarah Baracks for research assistance with data analysis. Thanks to Sandra Loughlin and Nicole Scifo for sharing feedback and expertise.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

bio.title: Bio
bio.p: Alida Anderson is an Assistant Professor of Special Education in the School of Education, Teaching and Health at American University, Washington, DC. Alida’s research interests are in language acquisition, literacy development, and learning-related challenges to literacy. Her research focuses on the contextualization of language to support students with a range of literacy-related challenges.
